title: What are some other ways to express 'so-so' in Spanish besides 'Así así'? - Quora

response.answer_text: To the answers already given I would add a common one that works in the context of "How was the movie?" - Vaya (normally followed by "regular") - Puff, vaya.... regular (note that "regular" in Spanish carries a different meaning than "regular" in English, which normally means "habitual, frecuente"). - Sin más A familiar colloquial expression spun off from "regular" is - Regulín, regulán Then in a different context, if someone is asking whether you have understood sonething well and you want to say "ermmm so so": - Más o menos - mmm no se yo que decirte  And finally a very good option for this other context: "How are you today"? is replying laconically with just the verb - ¿Qué tal estás hoy? _Estoy (I will say no more, you get what I mean) - ¿Qué tal estáis por aquí? _Estamos (You'd better don't get us started)

To be frank I think "así-así" is more commonly said by people who learned Spanish as a second language. My personal experience is that Spanish speakers would pretty much universally use "más o menos". I did wonder if I was just making an assumption based on my own upbringing. That it might be more popular in other countries. So I am glad to see people from other Spanish speaking countries confirming my suspicion. I was so confused when I heard people learning Spanish in college using it. That's when I found that it is commonly found in textbooks for learning Spanish and taught as almost a "default" answer. It actually made me doubt whether French speakers really say "comme ci, comme ça" or if that's also a French textbook thing.
